reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading comes from 乾く.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Instead of saying "no" you say "na," and instead of saying "na" you say <reading>いな</reading>. 

Note that 否 can also be read いや, which is a common way to say “no” in modern Japanese, but that reading is almost always written in kana.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Which <vocabulary>garden</vocabulary> is the Garden of Eden? <reading>その</reading> garden! That garden right next to you is the Garden of Eden!

It can also use the on'yomi, though, which you've already learned. When it takes the on'yomi and is used as a standalone word, it usually refers to some kind of institution, like a 幼稚園.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What are you trying <vocabulary>to dangle</vocabulary>? You're dangling a <reading>ta</reading>co (た) in front of a hungry person. He just wants the taco, and you keep dangling it like that.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji, which is fairly unusual, but then graveyards are unusual and special places. You've learned both of these readings before, so you should be able to read this on your own, but here's a reminder for 墓 just in case:

When you're finally dead and buried in a <vocabulary>graveyard</vocabulary>, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the <reading>Haka</reading> (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You know the reading for 天, but 然 uses a different reading from what you learned. So here's a mnemonic to help you:

One thing that definitely isn't <vocabulary>natural</vocabulary> are <reading>nen</reading>doroids (ねん). Remember, the little plastic figurines? Have you ever seen an anime figurine growing naturally in a field before? Yup, me neither. Not very natural.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 皇 is read as のう here. You just found out you can never be the Emperor of Japan because you aren't Japanese. <reading>NOOOOOOOOOOOOO</reading>~ (のう).

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You try <vocabulary>to obstruct</vocabulary> a woman coming your way (see kanji). As she gets close, she roars, "I am <reading>Sama(n)tha</reading>!" (さまた) You shall let me pass!" You don't argue with Samanthas. Get out of her way!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading for 家 is an exceptional one. It is や, because when your landlord asks if you paid your rent, you always say <reading>yah</reading> (や), whether you did or not.
You are <vocabulary>revered</vocabulary> because of your <reading>Toe toe</reading> (とうと), which is a toe on your toe. It's weird, but people seem to like it.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word uses the kun'yomi readings of all three kanji. The 小 and the 粉 both use kun'yomi that you haven't learned yet, but luckily they are both the same! Just think about how "small" things are like <reading>子</reading> (こ), and "powder" is also small. So both 小 and 粉 are read こ.
You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!
You've already learned all these readings. You should be able to read this on your own. And no, that's not a far-fetched argument, or a lame excuse for not writing a mnemonic.

This is a slightly unusual case because both kanji use the kun'yomi. You haven't learned that reading for 候 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What? You've become a <vocabulary>freeloader</vocabulary>? I can't believe you've gone <reading>so low</reading> (そうろう)!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This word shares the same reading as 広い. That means 拡がる is read as <reading>ひろ</reading>がる.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Of course, just to be dirty, the people who made up this word decided to use a kanji that read as かく. Dirty old monks that could see the future and speak English, ugh.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word 掃除 as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Who is doing the <vocabulary>chastity</vocabulary> thing? That <reading>missa, oh</reading> (みさお), yes she is.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A guy using <reading>eye arts</reading> (あやつ) isn't a great guy, it's the type of guy who might try <vocabulary>to manipulate</vocabulary> you via hypnosis of the eyes.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading of the 散 comes from 散る. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 散る, so you should be able to read it already! 

Note that this word is almost always written in kana, and チラシ is much more common than ちらし.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 散歩 as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
If anyone is going <vocabulary>to live one's life</vocabulary>, it's gotta be the great <reading>Ku</reading>blai Khan (く). He conquered most of the world and was super badass.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The beginning of the word <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary> is actually pretty similar to this word's reading. さわ = "swa"? I'd say it's close enough to make a mnemonic out of in your head.
The reading is 泥 plus the reading for 棒 put together.
The readings are the vocab readings of the two words, 泥 and 沼.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know the on'yomi for 温, but not for 厚, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The most <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> Tofugu staff has to be <reading>on</reading>ion <reading>こう</reading>いち. It's an onion that jumps in for こういち whenever he's not at the office. He's the most <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> soul you could imagine, never yelling at anyone. The ideal boss, really.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the two vocab words, 灰 and 皿, put together.
This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

What is making things <vocabulary>get hot and sticky</vocabulary>? Not many people know this, but it’s actually all of the cows going <reading>moo</reading> (む). With how much they moo, they create so much steam that everything is turning hot and sticky. Who could’ve known?!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If something starts <vocabulary>to ripen</vocabulary> too much, it gets all gross, and you're all like, "<reading>ew</reading> (う), that's gross."
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Look at your <reading>coat</reading> (こと), now look at mine. They are different. If you look at them, they are going <vocabulary>to differ</vocabulary>.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Please keep heaping up the food. I want <reading>more</reading> (もる), more, more.

This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 真 and an irregular reading for 似. You've already learned the reading for 真, but here's a mnemonic to help you with 似:

What are you doing an <vocabulary>imitation</vocabulary> of? A horse! You gallop around <reading>neigh</reading>ing (ね) at the top of your lungs! That's a pretty good imitation.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.
The reading is the readings for 窓 and the reading for 口.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You get a horrible <vocabulary>tendon</vocabulary> injury, making it so you can't walk anymore. You're so upset that you blame it on Jesus. So, you go and <reading>sue Je</reading>sus for this tendon injury, and win in court, amazingly.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
So you're supplying something... let's say nuclear warheads... to <reading>Osa</reading>ma Bin Laden. You gonna be in soooo much trouble, especially since it's zombie Osama Bin Laden.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from 編集 should help you.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. OH <reading>HAI</reading> THERE LUNG. OH HAI THERE YOU.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 華やか. Note the second はな becomes ばな, to be <reading>はなばな</reading>しい.
Something is so <vocabulary>remarkable</vocabulary> you let out <reading>one jeer</reading> (いちじる) at the opposing team. Just one, because you're not that mean.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 倉 and 庫. They're all basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (<reading>くら</reading>).
"<reading>Yo, so, oh</reading>, you gonna wear that <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary> today or what?"
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.
This word is 裏 and 切る's readings, put together.
The reading is 裏 plus 切る put together into one word.
The reading is 裏 and 口 put together into one word.
The reading is 裏 and 通り put together into one word.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 物 takes its もつ reading, which makes sense since it sounds like 持つ, which is "to hold." What is this freighter doing? It's holding freight! So, that's how you can remember that bit.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 貸 is read as たい for this one. What is your rental? It is a <reading>tie</reading> (たい) fighter. Sweet.
This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 除く. It's just the te-form of it.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 離れる.
The reading comes from 驚く. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledge.
